elements.content: This paper reports four homochiral zinc phosphonates, α-(S)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (1), α-(R)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (2), β-(S)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (3), and β-(R)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (4) [pempH2 = (1-phenylethyl)amino]methylphosphonic acid]. Both 1 and 2 are enantiomers, crystallizing in an orthorhombic P212121 space group, while 3 and 4 are polymorphic phases of 1 and 2, respectively, crystallizing in a monoclinic P21 space group. The polymorphism is induced by temperature or additional organic molecules.
elements.clean_text: This paper reports four homochiral zinc phosphonates, α-(S)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (1), α-(R)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (2), β-(S)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (3), and β-(R)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (4) [pempH2 = (1-phenylethyl)amino]methylphosphonic acid]. Both 1 and 2 are enantiomers, crystallizing in an orthorhombic P212121 space group, while 3 and 4 are polymorphic phases of 1 and 2, respectively, crystallizing in a monoclinic P21 space group. The polymorphism is induced by temperature or additional organic molecules.

elements.content: Homochiral zinc phosphonates α-(S)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (1), α-(R)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (2), β-(S)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (3), and β-(R)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (4) [pempH2 = [(1-phenylethyl)amino]methylphosphonic acid] are reported. Both 1 and 2 are enantiomers, while 3 and 4 are polymorphic phases of 1 and 2, respectively, induced by temperature or additional organic molecules.
elements.clean_text: Homochiral zinc phosphonates α-(S)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (1), α-(R)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (2), β-(S)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (3), and β-(R)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (4) [pempH2 = [(1-phenylethyl)amino]methylphosphonic acid] are reported. Both 1 and 2 are enantiomers, while 3 and 4 are polymorphic phases of 1 and 2, respectively, induced by temperature or additional organic molecules.

elements.content: Chiral coordination polymers have been of intense current interest mainly because of their potential applications in the areas of enantioselective catalysis and separation. Among the different approaches to introducing chirality, the main synthetic strategy is to use optically pure chiral multidentate ligands. By employment of enantiomerically pure phosphonic acids, a few chiral metal phosphonates have been prepared and crystallographically characterized. These include layer compounds (R)-α-Zn(O3PCH2P(O)(C6H5)(CH3)), (R)-α-Zn(O3PCH2P(O)(C6H5)(C2H5))·H2O, and (R)-β-Zn(O3PCH2P(O)(C6H5)(CH3))·H2O, chain compounds Ln[(S)-HO3PCH2NHC4H7CO2]3·2H2O (Ln = Tb, Dy, Eu, Gd),three-dimensional compound Zn2[(S)-O3PCH2NHC4H7CO2]2, and lamellar or pillared layered lanthanide diphosphonates based on derivatives of 1,1′-binaphthalene-6,6′-bisphosphonic acid. Some chiral porous zirconium phosphonates have also been reported that show promising heterogeneous asymmetric catalytic properties. In this paper, we use an enantiopure organic phosphonic acid, (S)- or (R)-[(1-phenylethyl)amino]methylphosphonic acid (pempH2), to react with zinc salts under hydrothermal conditions. Homochiral zinc phosphonates α-(S)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (1) and α-(R)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (2) are obtained successfully. More interestingly, the presence of organic molecules in the reaction mixture or a higher reaction temperature can lead to new phases, β-(S)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (3) and β-(R)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (4), which are polymorphic to compounds 1 and 2, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Chiral coordination polymers have been of intense current interest mainly because of their potential applications in the areas of enantioselective catalysis and separation. Among the different approaches to introducing chirality, the main synthetic strategy is to use optically pure chiral multidentate ligands. By employment of enantiomerically pure phosphonic acids, a few chiral metal phosphonates have been prepared and crystallographically characterized. These include layer compounds (R)-α-Zn(O3PCH2P(O)(C6H5)(CH3)), (R)-α-Zn(O3PCH2P(O)(C6H5)(C2H5))⋅H2O, and (R)-β-Zn(O3PCH2P(O)(C6H5)(CH3))⋅H2O, chain compounds Ln[(S)-HO3PCH2NHC4H7CO2]3⋅2H2O (Ln = Tb, Dy, Eu, Gd),three-dimensional compound Zn2[(S)-O3PCH2NHC4H7CO2]2, and lamellar or pillared layered lanthanide diphosphonates based on derivatives of 1,1'-binaphthalene-6,6'-bisphosphonic acid. Some chiral porous zirconium phosphonates have also been reported that show promising heterogeneous asymmetric catalytic properties. In this paper, we use an enantiopure organic phosphonic acid, (S)- or (R)-[(1-phenylethyl)amino]methylphosphonic acid (pempH2), to react with zinc salts under hydrothermal conditions. Homochiral zinc phosphonates α-(S)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (1) and α-(R)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (2) are obtained successfully. More interestingly, the presence of organic molecules in the reaction mixture or a higher reaction temperature can lead to new phases, β-(S)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (3) and β-(R)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (4), which are polymorphic to compounds 1 and 2, respectively.

elements.content: It is well-known that controlling polymorphism is of great interest in the fields of materials science and pharmacology because the various polymorphs of the same substance may have significantly different physical properties. The crystallization of polymorphs could be affected by such factors as temperature, additives, solvents, cooling rate, interface, etc. Polymorphism in metal phosphonates has been rare. As far as we are aware, the only example is a nanotubular uranyl phenylphosphonate (UO2)3(HO3PC6H5)2(O3PC6H5)2·H2O, which shows δ- and ϵ-polymorphs, both crystallizing in orthorhombic space group P212121. In the higher temperature ϵ phase, a tilting of the organic groups to accommodate the nanotubes more efficiently is observed. Polymorphism of homochiral metal phosphonates has never been reported.
elements.clean_text: It is well-known that controlling polymorphism is of great interest in the fields of materials science and pharmacology because the various polymorphs of the same substance may have significantly different physical properties. The crystallization of polymorphs could be affected by such factors as temperature, additives, solvents, cooling rate, interface, etc. Polymorphism in metal phosphonates has been rare. As far as we are aware, the only example is a nanotubular uranyl phenylphosphonate (UO2)3(HO3PC6H5)2(O3PC6H5)2⋅H2O, which shows δ- and ϵ-polymorphs, both crystallizing in orthorhombic space group P212121. In the higher temperature ϵ phase, a tilting of the organic groups to accommodate the nanotubes more efficiently is observed. Polymorphism of homochiral metal phosphonates has never been reported.

elements.content: Hydrothermal reactions of (S)-pempH2 or (R)-pempH2 with ZnSO4·7H2O and NaCl in a 1:1:0.5 molar ratio, adjusted to pH = 5.7 by NaOH at 140 °C, afforded colorless platelike crystals of 1 and 2, respectively. Complexes 3 and 4 were obtained by following a similar procedure except at 160 °C or using additional organic molecules such as racemic 3-hydroxypiperidine, ethanolamine, (CH3)4NOH, and (C2H5)4NOH. The same compounds can be obtained without NaCl by using ZnCl2 instead of ZnSO4 as the starting material.
elements.clean_text: Hydrothermal reactions of (S)-pempH2 or (R)-pempH2 with ZnSO4⋅7H2O and NaCl in a 1:1:0.5 molar ratio, adjusted to pH = 5.7 by NaOH at 140 °C, afforded colorless platelike crystals of 1 and 2, respectively. Complexes 3 and 4 were obtained by following a similar procedure except at 160 °C or using additional organic molecules such as racemic 3-hydroxypiperidine, ethanolamine, (CH3)4NOH, and (C2H5)4NOH. The same compounds can be obtained without NaCl by using ZnCl2 instead of ZnSO4 as the starting material.

elements.content: Single-crystal structural analyses reveal that complexes 1 and 2 are enantiomers crystallizing in the orthorhombic system, chiral space group P212121 (No. 19). Take compound 1 as an example. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains two independent Zn atoms, two phosphonate ligands, and one Cl− anion (Figure ). Both Zn1 and Zn2 atoms adopt slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometries. Zn1 is coordinated to three phosphonate O atoms (O1, O5, and O3B) and one N atom (N1) from three phosphonate ligands, with Zn1−O and Zn1−N bond lengths being 1.872(3)−1.983(3) and 2.044(3) Å, respectively. The four coordination sites around Zn2 are provided by three phosphonate O atoms (O2A, O4, and O6C) and one Cl− anion. The Zn2−O and Zn2−Cl bond lengths are 1.948(3)−1.997(3) and 2.201(1) Å, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal structural analyses reveal that complexes 1 and 2 are enantiomers crystallizing in the orthorhombic system, chiral space group P212121 (No. 19). Take compound 1 as an example. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains two independent Zn atoms, two phosphonate ligands, and one Cl- anion (Figure ). Both Zn1 and Zn2 atoms adopt slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometries. Zn1 is coordinated to three phosphonate O atoms (O1, O5, and O3B) and one N atom (N1) from three phosphonate ligands, with Zn1-O and Zn1-N bond lengths being 1.872(3)-1.983(3) and 2.044(3) Å, respectively. The four coordination sites around Zn2 are provided by three phosphonate O atoms (O2A, O4, and O6C) and one Cl- anion. The Zn2-O and Zn2-Cl bond lengths are 1.948(3)-1.997(3) and 2.201(1) Å, respectively.

elements.content: Coordination geometries of Zn in 1 with an atomic labeling scheme. Thermal ellipsoids are at the 30% probability level. All H atoms except those attached to N and chiral C atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  Coordination geometries of Zn in 1 with an atomic labeling scheme. Thermal ellipsoids are at the 30% probability level. All H atoms except those attached to N and chiral C atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: There are two crystallographically different phosphonate ligands (pemp2− and pempH−). pemp2− behaves as a tetradentate ligand. It chelates to Zn1 through O1 and N1 atoms and coordinates to the equivalent Zn1 and Zn2 via O3 and O2 atoms, respectively (Scheme a). pempH− serves as a tridentate ligand, with each of its three phosphonate O atoms binding to one Zn1 and two equivalent Zn2, respectively (Scheme b). Consequently, each {ZnO3N} or {ZnO3Cl} tetrahedron is corner-shared with three {CPO3} tetrahedra and vice versa, leading to a two-dimensional inorganic layer in the ab plane where helical chains of −Zn1−O−P−O− and −Zn2−O−P−O− are running along the a axis and are alternatively arranged along the b axis (Figure ). Hydrogen-bond interactions are found between the amino N and phosphonate O atoms within the layer. The N1···O4, N2···O1, N2···O6i, and N2···O2 distances are 3.073(5), 2.981(4), 2.868(5), and 3.051(4) Å, respectively (symmetry code: i, x − 1/2, −y + 3/2, −z + 1). The organic groups are grafted onto the two sides of the inorganic layer. van der Waals interactions dominate between the layers.
elements.clean_text: There are two crystallographically different phosphonate ligands (pemp2- and pempH-). pemp2- behaves as a tetradentate ligand. It chelates to Zn1 through O1 and N1 atoms and coordinates to the equivalent Zn1 and Zn2 via O3 and O2 atoms, respectively (Scheme a). pempH- serves as a tridentate ligand, with each of its three phosphonate O atoms binding to one Zn1 and two equivalent Zn2, respectively (Scheme b). Consequently, each {ZnO3N} or {ZnO3Cl} tetrahedron is corner-shared with three {CPO3} tetrahedra and vice versa, leading to a two-dimensional inorganic layer in the ab plane where helical chains of -Zn1-O-P-O- and -Zn2-O-P-O- are running along the a axis and are alternatively arranged along the b axis (Figure ). Hydrogen-bond interactions are found between the amino N and phosphonate O atoms within the layer. The N1⋅⋅⋅O4, N2⋅⋅⋅O1, N2⋅⋅⋅O6i, and N2⋅⋅⋅O2 distances are 3.073(5), 2.981(4), 2.868(5), and 3.051(4) Å, respectively (symmetry code: i, x - 1/2, -y + 3/2, -z + 1). The organic groups are grafted onto the two sides of the inorganic layer. van der Waals interactions dominate between the layers.

elements.content: Complexes 3 and 4 are enantiomers and crystallize in the monoclinic system, chiral space group P21 (No. 4). Both contain the same composition as those of 1 and 2 and show layer structures similar to those of 1 and 2, respectively. Hence, 3 is selected to compare with 1. The Zn−O, Zn−N, and Zn−Cl bond lengths of 3 are 1.845(5)−1.988(9), 2.033(7) and 2.196(3) Å, respectively, slightly different from those of 1 (Figure ). Hydrogen-bond interactions are again observed within the layer, with the N1···O6, N2···O1, N2···O2, and N2···O4ii distances being 3.075(8), 2.964(8), 3.038(1), and 2.873(8) Å, respectively (symmetry code: ii, 2 − x, 1/2 + y, 2 − z). A significant structural difference between 3 and 1 lies in the packing modes of the layers. In compound 1, neighboring layers are stacked along the c axis and repeat in an ···ABAB··· sequence, while in compound 3, they are stacked in the sequence of ···AA··· (Figure ). The layer-to-layer separations are 13.420 Å for 1 and 13.969 Å for 3.
elements.clean_text: Complexes 3 and 4 are enantiomers and crystallize in the monoclinic system, chiral space group P21 (No. 4). Both contain the same composition as those of 1 and 2 and show layer structures similar to those of 1 and 2, respectively. Hence, 3 is selected to compare with 1. The Zn-O, Zn-N, and Zn-Cl bond lengths of 3 are 1.845(5)-1.988(9), 2.033(7) and 2.196(3) Å, respectively, slightly different from those of 1 (Figure ). Hydrogen-bond interactions are again observed within the layer, with the N1⋅⋅⋅O6, N2⋅⋅⋅O1, N2⋅⋅⋅O2, and N2⋅⋅⋅O4ii distances being 3.075(8), 2.964(8), 3.038(1), and 2.873(8) Å, respectively (symmetry code: ii, 2 - x, 1/2 + y, 2 - z). A significant structural difference between 3 and 1 lies in the packing modes of the layers. In compound 1, neighboring layers are stacked along the c axis and repeat in an ⋅⋅⋅ABAB⋅⋅⋅ sequence, while in compound 3, they are stacked in the sequence of ⋅⋅⋅AA⋅⋅⋅ (Figure ). The layer-to-layer separations are 13.420 Å for 1 and 13.969 Å for 3.

elements.content: The structural and composition similarity of compound 3 to 1 suggests that the two compounds are polymorphic isomers. Considering that the other experimental conditions are almost the same in preparing the two compounds, the polymorphism could be induced by temperature or by the presence of the additional organic molecules. The cell volume of 3 is 1.2% smaller than that of 1, indicating that 3 could be thermodynamically more stable. This is supported by the experiments; e.g., higher reaction temperature favors the formation of 3 instead of 1. The same conclusion is held for 2 and 4.
elements.clean_text: The structural and composition similarity of compound 3 to 1 suggests that the two compounds are polymorphic isomers. Considering that the other experimental conditions are almost the same in preparing the two compounds, the polymorphism could be induced by temperature or by the presence of the additional organic molecules. The cell volume of 3 is 1.2% smaller than that of 1, indicating that 3 could be thermodynamically more stable. This is supported by the experiments; e.g., higher reaction temperature favors the formation of 3 instead of 1. The same conclusion is held for 2 and 4.

elements.content: Solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra were measured on KBr pellets for compounds 1−4 (Figure ). Clearly, compounds 1 and 3 exhibit positive Cotton effects while 2 and 4 show negative Cotton effects at the same wavelengths (254, 261, and 268 nm), reflecting that the optical activities of these compounds originate from the chiral organic phosphonate ligands. For compounds 1 and 2, the opposite sign of Cotton effects confirms that they are a pair of enantiomers. Similarly, compounds 3 and 4 are also a pair of enantiomers. The second harmonic generation (SHG) properties of powder samples 1−4 were also studied. The results indicate that both 1 and 2 exhibit SHG responses about 0.4 times that of urea, while 3 and 4 exhibit SHG responses about 0.5 times that of urea.
elements.clean_text: Solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra were measured on KBr pellets for compounds 1-4 (Figure ). Clearly, compounds 1 and 3 exhibit positive Cotton effects while 2 and 4 show negative Cotton effects at the same wavelengths (254, 261, and 268 nm), reflecting that the optical activities of these compounds originate from the chiral organic phosphonate ligands. For compounds 1 and 2, the opposite sign of Cotton effects confirms that they are a pair of enantiomers. Similarly, compounds 3 and 4 are also a pair of enantiomers. The second harmonic generation (SHG) properties of powder samples 1-4 were also studied. The results indicate that both 1 and 2 exhibit SHG responses about 0.4 times that of urea, while 3 and 4 exhibit SHG responses about 0.5 times that of urea.

elements.content: In summary, we report four novel enantiopure zinc phosphonates synthesized by hydrothermal reactions of (S)- or (R)-[(1-phenylethyl)amino]methylphosphonic acid and zinc sulfate under hydrothermal conditions, namely, α-(S)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (1), α-(R)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (2), β-(S)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (3), and β-(R)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (4). The results demonstrate that polymorphism of chiral zinc phosphonates can be induced by temperature or by additional organic molecules. Further work is in progress to prepare novel homochiral materials based on phosphonates with interesting chemical and physical properties.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we report four novel enantiopure zinc phosphonates synthesized by hydrothermal reactions of (S)- or (R)-[(1-phenylethyl)amino]methylphosphonic acid and zinc sulfate under hydrothermal conditions, namely, α-(S)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (1), α-(R)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (2), β-(S)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (3), and β-(R)-[Zn2(pemp)(pempH)Cl] (4). The results demonstrate that polymorphism of chiral zinc phosphonates can be induced by temperature or by additional organic molecules. Further work is in progress to prepare novel homochiral materials based on phosphonates with interesting chemical and physical properties.
